bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Maria Teresa Rojas, March 20, 1950

div1.p: Hench discusses Lydia's arthritis. He discusses the stalled effort to preserve Building No. 1 at Camp Lazear and asks if Rojas knows of any way to break the impasse. He assures her that plans for the memorial will in no way intrude on the nearby Rojas family home.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Maria Teresa Rojas, March 20, 1950
div1.opener:
March 20, 1950
Senorita Maria Titina Rojas
Quinta San Jose
Redencion
Marianao, Cuba
My dear Senorita Rojas:
div1.p:
I must apologize most sincerely to you for the long delay in
answering your letter to Mary dated December 20. I have been in the midst
of a degree of activity which has kept me so busy that I am far behind
with my correspondence. Please forgive me.

I am so sorry to hear that Miss Cabrera's sister has arthritis
and I wish that there was something that I could do to help.

The supplies of the two hormones, cortisone and ACTH, are so
extremely meager that they are being used only for investigative and
research purposes. Since most patients have to take them more or less
continuously to keep their arthritis under control, it simply cannot be
given as treatment and we have never used the word treatment in our reports.
We still consider our work of an investigative nature and we still have a
lot to learn about the best means of giving it, about how to prevent un-
desirable reactions which may occur, and so on. We are very optimistic
about these and are certain that the problems will be solved in due time
but it may be a year or two before these hormones are available as treatment.

In the meantime, I do hope that her sister is not just sitting
waiting for these hormones but is carrying on a program under the direction
of her attending physician using the orthodox procedures which will give
comfort and often help prevent deformities. Should her physician wish to
write to me at any time, I shall be glad to correspond with him.

May I thank you both for your many and very real kindnesses to
Mary when she was stranded in Paris. Your friendship meant much to her.
She was very lonesome and bored and she was thoroughly delighted with your
companionship. She often speaks of it with great pleasure.

We had hoped to run down to Cuba this spring but I have been so
excessively busy on many things that this has not been possible, but perhaps
next spring we can do so. As you know, we are very fond of Cuba and of
Havana.

I was greatly disappointed at the outcome of my last trip. As you
know, I worked very hard, interviewed innumerable officials, including the
Vice President; actually made and presented drawings of the plan for memorializing
Senorita Maria Titina Rojas
- 2 -
March 21, 1950
Camp Lazear and that part of the Finca San Jose where the caseta is and
was delighted to see in the newspaper that the Cuban government allotted
$50,000 for the care of the little building. I had tried to get permission
from various officials to build a protecting cover, perhaps galvanized iron,
around the caseta so that it would not be destroyed in the next windstorm.
We could hardly expect that it would survice much more, but I ran into the
fact that it was now a government “memorial” and therefore no private in-
dividual could do anything. I begged the Vice President to let me contribute
one or two thousand dollars myself and called his attention to the fact
that though it had been declared a memorial, it was still not protected and
nothing was being done but he very graciously and politely insisted that
they could not accept my money, that they would do that and would do so
right away. I am sure that he was behind the $50,000 bill that was passed.
Then I was most discouraged when I heard that with the incoming regime, all
unfinished business passed by the previous legislature was shelved. I have
discussed this with the Surgeon General of the United States Army and with
one or two other prominent personages in Washington but in view of the fact
that the caseta is now under the protection of the Cuban government, my
advisors in Washington hesitate greatly to interfere with what is Cuban
governmental business.
Do you know of any way that we can break this impasse?

Regardless of the unfortunate discussion as to the relative merits
of Finlay and the American Commission, the fact remains that the Finca San
Jose is a monument to both men as Finlay studied a couple of cases among monks
who were living in your quinta years before Reed and his colleagues erected
Camp Lazear on the rear of the Finca. Therefore, above all that spot is a place
memorable to all concerned.

You may rest assured, dear friends, that in my various discussions
I have made it clear that your home, the quinta, has no part in our plans. By
that I mean that nobody wishes to trouble you and I am sure that the Cuban
government understands that clearly, but it is a shame to see the little building
fall to ruin. My plans envisaged the erection of a small public health unit
on the spot with the little caseta in one large room and a little part for the
neighborhood to replace the cornfield in the front. These plans appeared to
have the hearty approval of the Vice President.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. PSH: alc
P.S.: Incidentally, this is the 50th anniversary of these events by the
American Commission.
